Award.AwardTitle: Oceanographic and Biological Implications of Arctic Sea-Ice Change: Evidence from Quaternary Benthic Foraminifers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide insights into the history of sea-ice cover and related evolution of deep-sea fauna by using newly discovered, continuous Arctic microfaunal records characterizing a transition from seasonally ice-free to perennially ice-covered and glacially-affected oceanic environments in the western Arctic. The major thrusts of the proposal will focus on
(1) investigating, in detail, foraminiferal distribution along with ostracodes and related sedimentary proxies in the Early Pleistocene, the time of mostly seasonal sea ice and little glacial inputs;
(2) comparing these records to correlative IODP data from the North Atlantic for a broad geographic and paleoclimatic context of at least hemispheric scale; and
(3) analyzing the distribution of foraminifers and ostracodes and, by proxy, sea-ice cover during the major climatic transitions and warm intervals in the younger stratigraphy in geographically distributed cores from the western Arctic Ocean.

The recently observed and ongoing changes in sea ice distribution are expected to have significant impact on endemic Arctic species. The data developed during this project will be useful to modelers trying to understand past changes in the Arctic system and predict future changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As Arctic sea ice retreats at accelerating rates, the future of Arctic marine biota becomes a paramount issue that requires close attention of scientific communities in both Earth and Life Sciences. Sedimentary records from the Arctic Ocean potentially can provide a wealth of information on its environmental and biological history; however, extracting this information is a big challenge because of very low biogenic content in sediment, widespread dissolution of calcareous and siliceous material, and complications with establishing age control. Foraminifers constitute the most commonly preserved group of skeletal organisms in Arctic Ocean deposits; nevertheless, their potential as proxy indicators of sea-ice environments has not yet been adequately explored. This project aimed to gain insights into the history of sea-ice cover and related evolution of deep-sea fauna by using newly discovered, continuous Arctic microfaunal records characterizing a transition from seasonally ice-free to perennially ice-covered and glacially-affected oceanic environments in the western Arctic.

The major focus of the proposal was on investigating in detail foraminiferal distribution, along with some other paleobiological (ostracodes) and related sedimentary proxies, in the Early Pleistocene and major succeeding interglacials, the times of mostly seasonal sea ice and little glacial inputs. Analyzing the stratigraphic distribution of foraminifers and, by proxy, sea-ice cover in geographically distributed cores from the western Arctic Ocean (Fig. 1) allowed for a characterization of Arctic paleoclimate during the major climatic transitions and warm intervals of the past at least one million years. Results of this research have a two-pronged implication: evolution of foraminiferal assemblages, combined with other paleoceanographic proxies, aids reconstructing paleo-sea-ice conditions, and also sheds light on the reaction of benthic biota to changing ice cover (e.g., Fig. 2).

Studies related to the main focus of this project deal with various topics of Arctic Quaternary stratigraphy and paleoceanography, including geochemical and mineralogical characterization of sediments, and enhancement of stratigraphic constraints. For example, strontium isotopes in foraminiferal tests were used for the first time as age controls for Quaternary (especially early Quaternary) sediments in the central Arctic Ocean.

Figure 1. Map of the Arctic Ocean with location of key sediment cores analyzed for foraminiferal distribution in this project. Arrows show major surface-water circulation features (TPD - Transpolar Drift, BG - Beaufort Gyre). Brown line – climatological late-20th century summer ice extent (15% concentration), pink line – 2012 summer ice extent (historical minimum). CAA – Canadian Arctic Archipelago; BS and FS - Bering and Fram Straits; NR, MR, and LR – Northwind, Mendeleev, and Lomonosov ridges, respectively.

Figure 2. Conceptual scheme of benthic foraminiferal assemblages buried in sediment as proxies of Arctic sea ice. Assemblages are categorized in relation to sea-ice conditions by characteristic leading species and interpreted abundance patterns. Single or double plus signs indicate relatively low and high abundances, respectively, controlled by relative intensity of test preservation and production.
